Intermediate Vocabulary - Page 5

Intermediate

Intermediate Vocabulary - Page 5

Continue expanding your intermediate vocabulary with these versatile words used in various professional and academic contexts.

Navigation

This is page 5 of 15. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Subsequent

/ˈsʌbsəkwənt/

adjective

Coming after something in time; following.

"The first meeting went well, and subsequent meetings were even better."

Synonyms: following, later, succeeding

Category: Sequence

Substitute

/ˈsʌbstəˌtuːt/

noun, verb

A person or thing acting or serving in place of another.

"We used honey as a substitute for sugar in the recipe."

Synonyms: replacement, alternative, stand-in

Category: Replacement

Sufficient

/səˈfɪʃənt/

adjective

Enough; adequate for the purpose or to satisfy a requirement.

"Do we have sufficient time to complete the project?"

Synonyms: enough, adequate, ample

Category: Quantity

Technique

/tekˈniːk/

noun

A way of carrying out a particular activity or achieving a particular result.

"She learned a new technique for solving math problems."

Synonyms: method, approach, procedure

Category: Method

Temporary

/ˈtempəreri/

adjective

Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent.

"The road closure is only temporary while they repair it."

Synonyms: short-term, brief, provisional

Category: Duration

Transition

/trænˈzɪʃən/

noun, verb

The process or a period of changing from one state or condition to another.

"The transition from high school to college can be challenging."

Synonyms: change, shift, transformation

Category: Change

Ultimate

/ˈʌltəmət/

adjective

Being or happening at the end of a process; final.

"Her ultimate goal is to become a doctor."

Synonyms: final, eventual, supreme

Category: Finality

Undertake

/ˌʌndərˈteɪk/

verb

To commit oneself to and begin an enterprise or responsibility.

"The company will undertake a major renovation project."

Synonyms: begin, embark on, commence

Category: Commitment

Valid

/ˈvælɪd/

adjective

Having a sound basis in logic or fact; reasonable or cogent.

"She raised a valid point during the discussion."

Synonyms: sound, reasonable, legitimate

Category: Logic

Vary

/ˈveri/

verb

To change or cause to change in character or form; typically in a minor way.

"Prices may vary depending on the season."

Synonyms: differ, change, fluctuate

Category: Change

Version

/ˈvɜːrʒən/

noun

A particular form of something differing in certain respects from an earlier form.

"This is the latest version of the software."

Synonyms: edition, variant, form

Category: Variation

Volume

/ˈvɑːljuːm/

noun

The amount of space that a substance or object occupies; quantity or power of sound.

"Please turn down the volume on the television."

Synonyms: capacity, amount, loudness

Category: Measurement
